methods.name: File
methods.description: A File object is created from your Bucket object using storage/bucket#file.

methods.name: copy
methods.description: Copy this file to another file. By default, this will copy the file to the same bucket, but you can choose to copy it to another Bucket by providing either a Bucket or File object.

examples.caption: You can pass in a variety of types for the destination. For all of the below examples, assume we are working with the following Bucket and File objects.
examples.code:
var bucket = storage.bucket('my-bucket');
var file = bucket.file('my-image.png');

examples.caption: If you pass in a string for the destination, the file is copied to its current bucket, under the new name provided.
If you pass in a Bucket object, the file will be copied to that bucket using the same name.
If you pass in a File object, you have complete control over the new bucket and filename.

exceptions.description: If the destination file is not provided.

methods.name: createReadStream
methods.description: Create a readable stream to read the contents of the remote file. It can be piped to a writable stream or listened to for 'data' events to read a file's contents.

examples.caption:
Downloading a File

The example below demonstrates how we can reference a remote file, then pipe its contents to a local file. This is effectively creating a local backup of your remote data.

methods.name: createWriteStream
methods.description:
Create a writable stream to overwrite the contents of the file in your bucket.

A File object can also be used to create files for the first time.

examples.caption:
Uploading a File

Now, consider a case where we want to upload a file to your bucket. You have the option of using storage/bucket#upload, but that is just a convenience method which will do the following.

Uploading a File with Metadata

One last case you may run into is when you want to upload a file to your bucket and set its metadata at the same time. Like above, you can use storage/bucket#upload to do this, which is just a wrapper around the following.

params.name: metadata
params.description: - Set the metadata for this file.

methods.name: getSignedUrl
methods.description:
Get a signed URL to allow limited time access to the file.

{@link https://developers.google.com/storage/docs/accesscontrol#Signed-URLs}

params.name: options.contentMd5
params.description: - The MD5 digest value in base64. If you provide this, the client must provide this HTTP header with this same value in its request.

params.name: options.contentType
params.description: - If you provide this value, the client must provide this HTTP header set to the same value.

params.name: options.expires
params.description: - Timestamp (seconds since epoch) when this link will expire.

params.name: options.extensionHeaders
params.description: - If these headers are used, the server will check to make sure that the client provides matching values.

exceptions.description: if an expiration timestamp from the past is given.

params.name: metadata
params.description: - The metadata you wish to set.
